docs.title: Welcome to ChallengeEU Project Documentation Page
docs.text: This Page serves as a way do document the way stuff in ChallengeEU is build.

docs.title: Intro to documentation
docs.text: Document how to document :)

docs.title: CSS Variables
docs.text:
:root {
  /* Primary */
  --orange-light: #F16E22;
  --orange-dark:  #571714;

  /* Neutrals */
  --white:        #FFFFFF;
  --off-white:    #F2F0EB;
  --gray-light:   #CCCEED;
  --gray-dark:    #2A2C37;

  /* Accents */
  --pink-light:   #FAE4F1;
  --pink-dark:    #FBBFEC;
  --purple-light: #D0A5EB;
  --purple-dark:  #621782;
  --yellow-light: #FAEEB0;
  --yellow-dark:  #FBD83D;
  --green-light:  #A6C3A3;
  --green-dark:   #016220;
  --blue-light:   #BAD4FF;
  --blue-dark:    #5692FF;
  --navy-light:   #B7C9ED;
  --navy-dark:    #193D69;
}

docs.title: Logo – A Visual Expression of the Brand
docs.text: The ChallengeEU logo captures collaboration, progress, and purpose.

docs.title: Symbol
docs.text:
• 9 rays = 9 partner universities
  • Outward motion = shared direction & innovation
  • Unity through action, not uniformity

docs.title: Wordmark
docs.text:
• "challenge" – forward-leaning ll = motion & ambition
  • "EU" – stable, formal = institutional strength
  • Contrast = youthful energy + structural integrity

docs.title: Logo Variants
docs.text: Variant Use Case Horizontal Lockup Default (symbol + wordmark) Horizontal Expanded + "European University Alliance" Vertical Micro Small spaces (stacked) Vertical Macro Large banners (centered) Symbol Only Icons, avatars, merch Typography Only Formal docs, subtle use

docs.title: Minimum Size
docs.text:
• Digital: 40 px height
  • Print: 3 mm height

docs.title: Solid Colors
docs.text:
• Use white logo on dark/orange
  • Use black logo on light
  • Never use unapproved colors

docs.title: Photos
docs.text:
• White logo on dark images
  • Full-color/black on light
  • Add subtle overlay if needed
  • Avoid noisy backgrounds

docs.title: Incorrect Usage
docs.text: Don't Change colors Outline or stroke Use low-res Crop or distort Rotate (unless pattern) Insert into text Mirror/flip Use Key Visual signets as logo

docs.title: Typography
docs.text: Typography supports the voice of ChallengeEU — clear, confident, and professional. This section introduces the selected typefaces and their usage rules to ensure consistency and legibility across all brand materials.

docs.title: Primary Typeface: Alegreya
docs.text:
Alegreya is a humanist serif with a calligraphic feeling, conveying a dynamic and varied rhythm. Perfect for long-form content and editorial layouts.

Typeface available for download: Alegreya – Google Fonts

docs.title: Weights & Styles
docs.text: Weight Example Regular Alegreya Regular Regular Italic Alegreya Regular Italic Medium Alegreya Medium Medium Italic Alegreya Medium Italic Bold Alegreya Bold Bold Italic Alegreya Bold Italic ExtraBold Alegreya ExtraBold ExtraBold Italic Alegreya ExtraBold Italic

docs.title: Implementation (Web)
docs.text: <link href="https://fonts.googleapis.com/css2?family=Alegreya:wght@400;500;700;800&family=Alegreya+Sans:wght@300;400;500;600;700;800&display=swap" rel="stylesheet">

docs.title: Paragraphs – Source Sans 3
docs.text:
Source Sans 3 (formerly Source Sans Pro) is Adobe’s first open-source typeface family.It is a sans-serif typeface optimized for user interfaces, offering excellent legibility at small sizes and across digital screens.

Typeface available for download: Source Sans 3 – Google Fonts

docs.title: Recommended Use
docs.text:
• Body text
  • UI labels & buttons
  • Forms & input fields
  • Captions & metadata

docs.title: Weights & Styles
docs.text: Weight Example Light Source Sans 3 Light Light Italic Source Sans 3 Light Italic Regular Source Sans 3 Regular Regular Italic Source Sans 3 Regular Italic Medium Source Sans 3 Medium Medium Italic Source Sans 3 Medium Italic SemiBold Source Sans 3 SemiBold SemiBold Italic Source Sans 3 SemiBold Italic Bold Source Sans 3 Bold Bold Italic Source Sans 3 Bold Italic

docs.title: Content
docs.text: # This is for wordpress content organization # This is for wordpress content organization

docs.title: Staging & Testing Workflow
docs.text: This document outlines the staging and testing workflow for the Challenge EU website, covering content, plugins, and code management.

docs.title: 1. Overview
docs.text:
The staging environment allows the team to safely test content, plugins, and code before publishing changes to the live site.

There are multiple ways to implement a staging environment:

  • Internal Staging: Using a subfolder or slug like /staging
  • Professional Staging: Dedicated staging server or subdomain
  • Local Development: Using LocalWP or Docker to test the site locally

Key principle: Content and code changes are tested independently before merging into live.

docs.title: 2. Website Structure
docs.text:
WordPress stores content and code in separate locations:

  • Content: wp-content/uploads (images, media) and the database
  • Themes: wp-content/themes/your-theme
  • Plugins: wp-content/plugins

Code changes (themes/plugins) are tracked via Git, while content changes are database-driven.

docs.title: 3.1 Content Staging
docs.text:
• Create draft pages, templates, and forms in a staging area
  • For example: /wp-content/staging or private pages within WordPress

  • Steps:

  • Playground Page (Private)

  • Test Elementor designs, forms, and page layouts
  • Export Templates/Forms
  • Once verified, export Elementor templates or forms
  • Publish Live Content
  • Import verified templates/forms to the live site
  • Content goes live safely without breaking existing pages

docs.title: 3.2 Plugin Staging
docs.text:
• Test new plugins in LocalWP or staging environment

  • Steps:

  • Clone the live website to LocalWP

  • Install and configure the plugin
  • Test functionality thoroughly
  • Only push tested plugins to staging or live site

docs.title: 3.3 Code Staging
docs.text:
• Manage themes and custom code via Git

  • Workflow:

  • Ensure that tested code changes are merged to staging before deploying live

docs.title: 4. Recommended Practices
docs.text:
• Design Approvals: All visual changes should be designed in Figma and approved before staging
  • Content Testing: Draft content and media should be staged in /wp-content/staging
  • Plugin Testing: Use LocalWP to experiment without affecting live site
  • Export & Import: Only move tested templates, forms, and plugins to live
  • Team Access: Only team members with access to staging and Git should manage changes

docs.title: 5. Tools & Options
docs.text:
• LocalWP: Local WordPress development environment for plugin and design testing
  • Docker: Optional containerized staging environment
  • GitHub Actions: Optional CI/CD pipeline for automated deployment of themes/plugins

docs.title: 6. Summary
docs.text:
Stage Location / Tool Purpose Content Staging /wp-content/staging Draft templates, forms, and media Plugin Testing LocalWP Test plugin functionality Code Changes Git Manage themes and custom code Staging Server Subdomain / Folder Test live-like environment safely Live Site Production Publish verified content and code

This workflow ensures that content, plugins, and code are tested independently before reaching the live site, reducing errors and downtime.
